coredata.dc:title: Constructing a conductive solid electrolyte interface by adding lithium nitrate into carbonate electrolyte for stable lithium metal anode
coredata.dc:creator: Fei, Jiafeng
Liu, Honghao
Wang, Rongjie
Guan, Mengjia
Li, Yongsheng
coredata.dc:description: Regulating the solid electrolyte interface (SEI) components through additives could improve uncontrollable lithium dendrites and unstable electrode/electrolyte interface, which hinder the practical application of lithium metal batteries (LMBs). In this work, the solubilization of lithium nitrate (LiNO3), whose reduction decomposition at the anode can promote dense Li deposition and robust N-rich SEI, was achieved in an ester-based electrolyte by using diglyme (G2) as a carrier solvent. Benefitting from the uniform Li deposition and stable SEI layer, the modified electrolyte exhibited a high Coulombic efficiency of 98% over 330 cycles, and demonstrated superb cycling stability for >1000 h in the Li||Li symmetric cell. In addition, the practical Li||LiFePO4 full cell manifested excellent cycling and rate performances with a high capacity retention of 94% after 400 cycles. Even under a high current density of 5C, the cells exhibited a remarkble average discharge specific capacity of 68.8 mAh g−1 over 300 cycles, and a reversible capacity of 152.2 mAh g−1 was attained with negligible capacity loss when the rate went back to 1C. This study offered a straightforward and economical method to regulate SEI components and suppress lithium dendrites by rational electrolyte modification.

Electrolyte additive
lithium metal anode
Robust SEI
Carbonate electrolyte

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Illustration of Li+ deposition behavior in different electrolyte systems.

(a) CV curves of Li||SS cells with different electrolytes scanning from −0.3 to 0.6 V. (b) Tafel plots of Li||Li symmetric cells with different electrolytes at the scan rate of 1 mV s−1. (c) EIS spectra of symmetric cells with different electrolytes before cycling. (d) Ionic conductivities of the BE-G2/LiNO3 and BE electrolyte.
Surface morphologies of Cu foils extracted from Li||Cu cells in (a, b) BE-G2/LiNO3 and (d, e) BE under the capacity of 1 mAh cm−2.
F 1 s XPS spectra of the SEI formed in (a) BE-G2/LiNO3 and (c) BE electrolyte. N 1 s XPS spectra of the SEI formed in (b) BE-G2/LiNO3 and (d) BE electrolyte.

(a) Coulombic efficiencies of Li||Cu cells with different electrolytes at 1 mA cm−2 and 1 mAh cm−2. The corresponding voltage profiles in Li||Cu half cells with (b) BE-G2/LiNO3 and (c) BE electrolyte.

(a) CE measurements of Li||Cu cells with different electrolytes by Aurbach's method. (b) The corresponding initial Li nucleation potential. (c) Cycling performance of Li||Li symmetric cell with different electrolytes at 1 mA cm−2 and 1 mAh cm−2. (d) Rate performance of Li||Li symmetric cells with different electrolytes.

(a) Rate performance of Li||LFP cells with different electrolytes. The corresponding voltage profiles of Li||LFP full cells with (b) BE-G2/LiNO3 and (c) BE electrolytes. (d) Cycling stability of Li||LFP full cells in different electrolytes at the current density of 2C.

head.ce:title: Constructing a conductive solid electrolyte interface by adding lithium nitrate into carbonate electrolyte for stable lithium metal anode

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Regulating the solid electrolyte interface (SEI) components through additives could improve uncontrollable lithium dendrites and unstable electrode/electrolyte interface, which hinder the practical application of lithium metal batteries (LMBs). In this work, the solubilization of lithium nitrate (LiNO3), whose reduction decomposition at the anode can promote dense Li deposition and robust N-rich SEI, was achieved in an ester-based electrolyte by using diglyme (G2) as a carrier solvent. Benefitting from the uniform Li deposition and stable SEI layer, the modified electrolyte exhibited a high Coulombic efficiency of 98% over 330 cycles, and demonstrated superb cycling stability for >1000 h in the Li||Li symmetric cell. In addition, the practical Li||LiFePO4 full cell manifested excellent cycling and rate performances with a high capacity retention of 94% after 400 cycles. Even under a high current density of 5C, the cells exhibited a remarkble average discharge specific capacity of 68.8 mAh g−1 over 300 cycles, and a reversible capacity of 152.2 mAh g−1 was attained with negligible capacity loss when the rate went back to 1C. This study offered a straightforward and economical method to regulate SEI components and suppress lithium dendrites by rational electrolyte modification.

ce:data-availability.ce:para: No data was used for the research described in the article.

ce:section.ce:para: With the advancement of electric automobiles, it is difficult for commercial lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) with graphite anode to satisfy the ever-growing requirements of energy density. Owing to its exceedingly high theoretical specific capacity (3860 mAh g−1, which is 10 times of the graphite anode in LIBs) and extra-low redox potential (−3.04 V vs standard hydrogen electrode), lithium metal anode has been regarded as the most promising substitute for conventional graphite anode [1,2]. Therefore, extensive attentions have been paid on lithium metal batteries (LMBs) over the past few years. However, several obstacles impede the commercial application of LMBs. First of all, adverse side reactions between the highly reactive Li metal and electrolyte lead to reduced Coulombic efficiency (CE) of the cells [3]. In addition, huge volume change makes the electrode material inevitably crush and crack after cycles, which results in fragile SEI and rapid capacity loss of LMBs. What's more, severe dendritic Li may puncture the separator and cause short circuit of the cell, causing cell failure [4,5].

Multiple constructive strategies have been proposed to solve these problems, including 3D substrates design [6], separator modification [7], artificial SEI layer [8], solid-state electrolyte [9] and electrolyte configuration [10]. Among them, optimization of electrolyte formulation is one of the most convenient and feasible approaches. As reported, the chemical composition and structure of SEI layer is directly affected by the decomposition products of electrolyte, which can be controlled by adjusting lithium salt, solvent or functional additive in the electrolyte [11,12]. Besides, the use of additives is the most cost-effective way since only a small amount of additives is required. Film-forming additives such as fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC) [13], difluoroethylene carbonate (DFEC), and vinylene carbonate (VC) [14] can participate in the formation of SEI [15]. Since lithium nitrate (LiNO3) with a low lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) energy level can be preferentially decomposed at the lithium metal anode (LMA) to construct a conductive N-enriched SEI layer [16–18], LiNO3 is reckoned as one of the most promising inorganic film-forming additives. Unfortunately, LiNO3 endows extremely low solubility (about 800 ppm) in commercial ester electrolytes which have been commonly utilized in high-voltage LMBs because of their excellent oxidation stability [19,20]. Therefore, it is urgent to employ reliable approaches to improve the solubility of LiNO3 in ester electrolytes for the development of high-voltage LMBs. In recent years, three main strategies have been innovatively proposed to introduce LiNO3 into carbonate electrolytes, including chemical solubilization, physical release and pre-reaction [21]. For instance, LiNO3 solubilization has been achieved by using strongly polar solvents as carrier solvents, such as tetramethylurea (TMU) [22], dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) [23,24], pyridine (Py), and tetraglyme (TGM) [25]. Yang et al. found that the combination of EC and EGD efficiently solubilized LiNO3 to 0.6 M, as opposed to 0.2 M LiNO3 dissolved in EC and DMC mixed solvents [26]. In addition, Wang et al. reported that the growth direction of deposited Li was dispersed by adding TMP/LiNO3 hybrid additive, which prevented dendritic Li from growing in one direction [27]. Therefore, the solubility of LiNO3 in carbonate electrolytes can be improved in the presence of appropriate cosolvents.

Herein, diglyme (G2) was proposed as a LiNO3 solubilizer to overcome the solubility limitation of LiNO3 in carbonate electrolyte, which is the result of relatively strong Lewis basicity due to the lone pair of oxygen atoms in the structure [28,29]. The modified carbonate electrolyte enabled homogeneous and dense Li deposition behavior, as well as improved electrochemical performances (Fig. 1 ). As a result, the modified electrolyte exhibited a much enhanced Coulombic efficiency of 98% in the Li||Cu cell and a stable cycling performance of 1000 h in the Li||Li symmetric cell. Meanwhile, the practical Li||LiFePO4 full cell demonstrated excellent cycling performance with a high capacity retention of 94% after 400 cycles. This work provides an efficient and economic strategy to realize superior electrochemical performance in practical LMBs.

To enable high energy density of LMBs, commercial carbonate electrolyte (1 M lithium hexafluorophosphate (LiPF6) in ethylene carbonate/diethyl carbonate (EC/DEC = 1: 1 by volume) with 10 wt% fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC), denoted as BE) was chosen as the baseline electrolyte due to its high oxidative stability (>4.5 V). G2 was proposed as a carrier solvent to dissolve LiNO3 in the BE owing to its strong Lewis basicity and good Li compatibility. As a result, 0.4 M LiNO3 could be dissolved in 1.4 mL baseline electrolyte with just 0.6 ml G2 as the cosolvent (denoted as BE-G2/LiNO3), which exhibits transparent solution without precipitation (Fig. S1, Supporting Information). It's well-known that lithium fluoride (LiF), as an important component of SEI, has a low Li+ diffusion energy barrier to help Li+ diffusion through the SEI, and a LiF-rich SEI can inhibit uncontrollable Li growth owing to its high modulus [8]. Therefore, a conductive SEI containing N and F elements can be generated on the surface of LMA as a result of the synergistic impact of LiNO3 and FEC for enhancing the performance of LMBs.

In order to prove the superiority of the as-prepared BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolyte, the kinetics of interfacial reaction was investigated by the following electrochemical tests. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurement in the potential range of −0.3-0.6 V was carried out to investigate the Li plating/stripping kinetics of Li||SS cells (Fig. 2a), in which the response current of the Li||Cu cell with BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolyte was much higher than that of the cell with BE, proving the faster reaction kinetics in the BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolyte due to the presence of G2/LiNO3 additive. Fig. 2b illustrates the Tafel curves of Li||Li symmetric cells with different electrolytes. The exchange current density (i0) obtained by fitting the Tafel curve is connected with the kinetics of ion transfer at the interface. The i0 value of BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolyte (0.44 mA cm−2) was over twice larger than that of BE (0.20 mA cm−2), verifying the enhanced charge transfer kinetics at the interface between BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolyte and Li anode. Additionally, to evaluate the electrochemical oxidation window of different electrolytes, linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) was conducted in the Li||Al cells at the scan rate of 1 mV s−1. Although introducing G2 into the electrolytes might compromise the oxidative stability, the addition of small amount of G2 still guaranteed that the electrochemical windows of the BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolytes were above 4.2 V(Fig. S2, Supporting Information), indicating the application feasibility of BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolytes in high-voltage battery systems.

Figure 2c and Fig. S3 showed the impedance evolution of symmetric cells in BE and BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolytes before cycling and after 50 cycles. The semicircles at the high-frequency region represent the SEI resistance (RSEI) and the charge transfer resistance (Rct), which is determined by the ionic conductivity of the SEI layer [30–32]. Obviously, the electrode/electrolyte interfacial resistance in the BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolyte was much smaller than that in BE. It was evident that the interfacial resistance of all cells decreases after 50 cycles, which should be attributed to the formation of the stable interface after the activation process. The schematic diagram of the equivalent circuit was shown in the insets of Fig. 2c and Fig. S3, where the Rs, Rsei, Rct and CPE represented the ohmic impedance, interfacial impedance, charge transfer impedance, and capacitance, respectively. Moreover, the detailed resistance values after equivalent fitting were listed in Table S1. The EIS results manifested that a more conductive SEI layer with high Li+ conductivity was formed in the BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolyte. Besides, the BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolyte (10.8 mS cm−1) demonstrated higher ionic conductivity than the BE electrolyte (6.5 mS cm−1), which was beneficial for the rapid and uniform Li stripping/plating process (Fig. 2d). All of these above results collaboratively proved that a more conductive and robust SEI layer was constructed at the interface of Li anode by using the BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolyte, which was expected to achieve enhanced electrochemical performance of LMBs.

The lithium deposition morphologies in different electrolytes were characterized by scanning electron microscope (SEM) technology (Fig. 3
). On the surface of Cu foil in BE (Fig. 3c-d), porous morphology and inhomogeneous Li plating with a thick layer of dendritic Li were visible, which might readily penetrate the separator and consume the limited electrolyte, deteriorating cycling stability and even causing an internal short circuit. However, the lithium deposition morphology in the BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolyte was uniform, compact and smooth (Fig. 3a-b), which helped to achieve improved electrochemical performances of the LMBs. As shown in the corresponding EDS mapping of the SEI formed in BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolyte, the N signals can be clearly seen and was uniformly distributed on the surface of Li anode. (Fig. S4b). The BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolyte improving the Li deposition uniformity was also confirmed by the cross-sectional SEM images. Fig. S5 illustrated cross-sectional Li deposition morphologies on the surface of Cu foils with different electrolytes. The Li deposited in BE electrolyte presented a rather loose structure with a thickness of approximately 27 μm, which confirmed that the Li deposition layer in BE electrolyte was highly loose and uneven. As for the BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolyte, homogeneous and compact Li deposition was obtained on the Cu substrate. The dense structure suppressed the side reactions between the newly deposited Li and electrolyte and reduced the thickness of Li deposition to 14 μm. Such obvious comparisons emphasized that the N-rich SEI derived from LiNO3 can prominently promote the uniform Li deposition morphology.

Furthermore, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out to investigate the chemical composition of the formed SEI in various electrolytes, as the stripping/plating kinetics and lithium deposition morphology were strongly correlated with the properties of SEI. As evidenced in the F 1 s spectra (Fig. 4a and Fig. 4c), typical LiF peaks were observed at 685.2 eV in both electrolytes without obvious change, which originated from the decomposition of FEC and LiPF6 salt in the electrolytes. It has been well acknowledged that LiF is a beneficial SEI component to guide homogeneous deposition of Li owing to its strong mechanical strength, low Li+ diffusion barrier, and high interfacial energy [33]. Besides, there was no discernible N 1 s signal in the SEI formed in BE, while the N 1 s spectrum of the SEI in BE-G2/LiNO3 showed two peaks at 400.2 and 398.3 eV (Fig. 4b), pointing to the formation of Li3N and LiNxOy components [34,35], respectively. It is widely reported that an SEI layer abundant with inorganic N-containing components (Li3N and LiNxOy) possesses high Li+ conductivity and mechanical strength, which facilitates compact and uniform lithium deposition [36]. Therefore, a favorable SEI layer abundant with LiF-Li3N components was generated in the BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolyte, which is beneficial for the improved Li stripping/plating behavior and reaction kinetics.

Coulombic efficiencies (CE) of Li stripping/plating processes of different electrolytes were assessed by galvanostatic cycling experiment of Li||Cu cells. As shown in Fig. 5a, the Li||Cu cell using BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolyte demonstrated sustained long-term performance over 330 cycles with an average CE of 98%, in contrast to the Li||Cu cell with BE, whose CE dropped to <85% within 150 cycles due to the uncontrollable growth of Li dendrites and unfavorable side reactions. Meanwhile, much smoother voltage plateaus with small voltage polarization between Li stripping/plating cycles were observed in the Li||Cu cell with BE-G2/LiNO3 than that of the cell with baseline electrolyte (Fig. 5b-c). Further increasing the current density to 3 mA cm−2 (Fig. S6, Supporting Information), the Li||Cu cell employing BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolyte still retained outstanding stripping/plating CE of 97% over 170 cycles, whereas the cell with BE kept stable for only 40 cycles. The nucleation and growth overpotentials at the initial stage of Li deposition in different electrolytes were displayed in Fig. S7, where the Li||Cu cell with the BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolyte delivered a much lower nucleation overpotential (9 mV) than that of the BE electrolyte (31 mV), reflecting that the nucleation barrier in the BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolyte was significantly reduced due to the formation of highly conductive LiF-Li3N enriched SEI layer, which subsequently promoted homogeneous Li deposition behavior as evidenced by the decreased growth overpotential (16 mV) in BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolyte [17].

Furthermore, the Li stripping/plating reversibility of various electrolytes were investigated by Aurbach's CE method. As shown in Fig. 6a, the average CE of BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolyte (99.12%) was significantly increased compared with the BE (95.96%), indicating the highly reversible Li stripping/plating process resulted from the reduced side reactions and suppressed Li dendrites in the BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolyte. Besides, it can be observed from Fig. 6b that the Li nucleation overpotential was significantly decreased from 135.5 mV to 63.9 mV by adding G2/LiNO3 additive into the baseline electrolyte, proving that LiNO3 promoted the formation of favorable SEI with high ionic conductivity. As depicted in Fig. 6c and Fig. S8, the Li||Li symmetric cell with the BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolyte exhibited superb long-term stability with stable polarization voltage for >1000 h at the cycling capacity of 1 mAh cm−2 and current density of 1 mA cm−2. In contrast, the Li||Li symmetric cell with BE experienced a sharp overpotential increase due to severe Li dendrite growth after cycling for 550 h. Since the performance and cycling stability of LMBs were significantly influenced by the deposition behavior, Li||Li symmetric cells were disassembled and observed after 50 cycles at 1 mA cm−2 and 1 mAh cm−2. The surface morphology of the Li anode in the BE was rough and fractured inhomogeneous (Fig. S9a-b, Supporting Information). However, dense and crack-free Li deposition morphology was obtained in BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolyte (Fig. S9c-d, Supporting Information), which was accorded with the Li deposition behavior in Li||Cu cells. Moreover, the rate performance of the Li||Li symmetric cell at different current densities under the cycling capacity of 1 mAh cm−2 was carried out, in which the overpotential of the cell with BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolyte was flatter and smaller than that of the symmetric cell with BE especially at high current densities (Fig. 6d). These improved electrochemical performance certificates the superiority of the modified BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolyte.

To verify the effectiveness of BE-G2/LiNO3 in practical application, Li||LiFePO4 full-cell configuration was assembled with high-areal-loading LiFePO4 (15 mg cm−2) as the cathode and Li metal as the anode. The rate performance in Fig. 7a demonstrated that higher discharge capacities were observed in the cell with BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolyte, especially at the high rate of 2C and 5C. Specifically, the cell using BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolyte exhibited considerable discharge capacities of 93.4 mAh g−1 at 5C, which was >1.7 times higher than that of the cell with BE (53.5 mAh g−1). Besides, when the rate went back to 1C, a reversible capacity of 152.2 mAh g−1 was attained with minimal capacity loss in the Li||LiFePO4 cell with BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolyte, certificating its excellent rate performance. Typical charge/discharge profiles in Fig. 7b-c further demonstrated this contrast. At high rate, the cell assembled with BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolyte showed smaller voltage polarizations than those of cell with BE.

In addition, Fig. 7d illustrates the long-term cycling performance of Li||LiFePO4 full cells with different electrolytes at the rate of 2C. The capacity retention sustained a high level of 94% after 400 cycles with BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolyte, while the BE electrolytes delivered a sharp capacity fading at about 120 cycles. In the following cycling performance test of Li||LFP cells under a high current density of 5C (Fig. S10, Supporting Information), the cells with BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolyte exhibited a higher average discharge specific capacity of 68.8 mAh g−1 than the cells with BE electrolyte (35.3 mAh g−1). By using BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolyte, the capacity retention of Li||LFP cells after 300 cycles sustained 84%, which was ascribed to the formation of robust SEI. The morphology of Li foils extracted from Li||LFP full cells was detected through the SEM, and as presented in Fig. S11, more uniform Li plating behavior was attained by using BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolyte, while the deposited Li manifested as porous structure with numerous needle-like dendritic Li in BE electrolyte. These comparisons demonstrate that our BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolyte formulation endows the potential in practical applications.

In summary, we have proposed a feasible and cost-effective method to improve the solubility of LiNO3 in the carbonate electrolyte by introducing diglyme (G2) as a solubilizer. Preferential reduction of LiNO3 yielded highly conductive N-rich inorganic components (Li3N and LiNxOy) in SEI which enabled rapid transport of Li+ and suppressed the growth of lithium dendrites, leading to uniform Li deposition and enhanced cycling performances. As a result, the BE-G2/LiNO3 electrolyte achieved a high CE of 98% for 330 cycles in the Li||Cu cells and remarkable long-term stability over 1000 h in the Li||Li cells. Moreover, Li||LFP cells realized excellent capacity retention of 94% after 400 cycles at the rate of 2C, which shows great electrochemical performance and potential for practical application.

Jiafeng Fei: Writing – original draft. Honghao Liu: Formal analysis. Rongjie Wang: Supervision. Mengjia Guan: Writing – review & editing, Supervision. Yongsheng Li: Supervision, Funding acquisition, Conceptualization.

ce:conflict-of-interest.ce:para: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.
